lessonOverview.title: Unit 6 - Lesson 2
structures: B: He’s/She’s wearing a brown jacket/yellow socks.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name eight clothes (T-shirt, trousers, scarf, skirt, dress, jacket, socks, trainers) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show clothing flashcards. Say: “This is a jacket.” Students repeat and mime wearing each item. Follow with a “stand up if you're wearing…” game.
stretchStrategies: Guess Who Tournament – In pairs, students describe a chosen person from SB visuals with “He’s got curly hair” / “She’s got freckles.” Partner guesses. Winners move on to challenge other pairs in a mini-tournament. Consolidates vocab + speaking + grammar.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about clothes using “What are you wearing?” / “What’s he/she wearing?” and respond with “I’m wearing...” / “He’s/She’s wearing...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Use cut-out figures or classmates. Ask: “What’s he/she wearing?” Students describe: “He’s wearing a T-shirt and jeans.” Use peer checking.
stretchStrategies: Guess Who Tournament – In pairs, students describe a chosen person from SB visuals with “He’s got curly hair” / “She’s got freckles.” Partner guesses. Winners move on to challenge other pairs in a mini-tournament. Consolidates vocab + speaking + grammar.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What are you wearing?” / “What’s he/she wearing?” / “I’m wearing ___.” / “He’s/She’s wearing ___.” to talk about clothes.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On the board, write the Q&A: “What are you wearing?” / “I’m wearing ___.” Students complete sentence starters using flashcards as prompts.
stretchStrategies: Guess Who Tournament – In pairs, students describe a chosen person from SB visuals with “He’s got curly hair” / “She’s got freckles.” Partner guesses. Winners move on to challenge other pairs in a mini-tournament. Consolidates vocab + speaking + grammar.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.
VYL: many words starting in sibilants prove extremely difficult (shirt, shorts, socks, shoes). Plurals for singular items (trousers, shorts)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
